{{oneref|date=June 2010}} {{Infobox OS | name = Trinity Rescue Kit | logo = [[Image:TrinityRescueKit.png]] | screenshot = | caption = | developer = Tom Kerremans | family = [[Linux]] | source model = [[Open source]] | working state = Current | latest release version = 3.4 build 367 | latest release date = {{release date|2010|08|16}} | language = [[English language|English]] | kernel type = [[Linux kernel|Linux]] | license = Unknown | website = http://trinityhome.org/trk }} '''Trinity Rescue Kit''' (also known as TRK) is a free [[command-line]] [[Live CD]] [[Linux distribution]] created especially for rescuing Windows PCs<ref name=schof>[[jack.schofield]]: [[The Guardian]] ''Technology: Ask Jack...Endless reboot'', 28th June 2007</ref> <ref name=PN052>Podnutz ''[http://www.podnutz.com/podnutz052?page=1 Episode 52: Trinity Rescue Kit]''</ref> It is aimed specifically at offline operations for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and Linux systems such as rescue, repair, password resets and [[disk cloning]]. It's [[virusscan]] encompases five [[antivirus programs]].<ref> Alison Diana ''Trinity Upgrades Linux Rescue Kit'' [[InformationWeek]] 17 August 2010 11:09 AM</ref>
Trinity Rescue Kit is bootable from a CD, USB media or a network using [[Preboot Execution Environment|PXE]]. Documentation for TRK exists both on the website, as well as in the console by using the command "trkhelp -l -t". Trinity Rescue Kit omits the standard Linux [[Manual page (Unix)|manual command]] in order to conserve space. In addition, there are tools to migrate TRK from an [[ISO image]] to a bootable USB device and vice versa.
Trinity Rescue Kit has a graphical startup menu based on [[SYSLINUX]] and vesamenu32 which is used to select boot options, but the OS is otherwise [[command-line]] only.
==History== Starting in 2001, after creating a bootable DOS-based CD of proprietary software for offline operations (named "The Vault"), Belgian developer, Tom Kerremans decided to create a free bootable Linux CD.<ref name=PN052>Podnutz ''[http://www.podnutz.com/podnutz052?page=1 Episode 52: Trinity Rescue Kit]''</ref>
The purpose would be to include free tools that could help rescue a Windows installation that was being problematic. Binaries and scripts from other distributions inspired the Trinity Rescue Kit. Sources included [[Mandriva]] 2005 and the [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] Cores 3 and 4. The startup procedure and methods, and many scripts, are custom-made for Trinity Rescue Kit.<ref>[http://trinityhome.org/Home/index.php?wpid=1&front_id=12 What is Trinity Rescue Kit?]</ref>
==Features== TRK 3.3 was based on Linux 2.6.26.
* 6 consoles (accessed using alt+F1, etc.) * The ability to update itself (antivirus definitions/drivers) if burned onto a CD-RW * Data Recovery Tools * Clone Windows over a network * Antivirus Scanner ** [[ClamAV]] ** [[F-Prot]] ** [[AVG Anti-Virus]] ** [[BitDefender]] ** [[Avast]] * Reset Windows passwords * Read/Write to [[NTFS]] partitions through [[ntfs-3g]] ** clonentfs allows copying of all used space on a drive ** Better support for Vista in build 321 * Edit partition layout * [[Secure Shell|SSH]] Server * [[Samba (software)|Samba]] server ** Share all local drives on network as a user or a guest * [[Logical Volume Management]] * [[Proxy server]] support * Bridging Capabilities ** Allows tcpdump when traffic passes other computers
